questions.text: How many axons comprise the optic nerve? How many axons comprise the optic nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The optic nerve is composed of approximately 1.2 million axons.

  • The optic nerve is formed by the axons of the retinal ganglion cells, which converge at the optic disc and exit the eye to form the nerve. These axons transmit visual information from the retina to the brain.
  • Within the optic nerve, these fibres are arranged into approximately 600 bundles by fibrous septae derived from the pia mater. Anatomically, the optic nerve is about 50 mm long and is divided into four segments:
    • Intraocular (optic nerve head): the shortest segment (1 mm deep, 1.5 mm vertical diameter), seen as the optic disc.
    • Intraorbital: 25 - 30 mm long, extending to the orbital apex, with a diameter of 3 - 4 mm due to myelination.
    • Intracanalicular: Around 6 mm long, passing through the optic canal, encased by dura fused to periosteum.
    • Intracranial: varies from 5 to 16 mm, vulnerable to damage from aneurysms or tumours.
  • Approximately 80% of the optic nerve fibres arise from the macular region, which contains about 90% of all retinal ganglion cells.
  • Microscopically, the optic nerve contains oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, and microglia, in contrast to true peripheral nerves, which are composed of Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and macrophages.
  • Similar to the brain's white matter, the optic nerve lacks regenerative capacity. Its axons become myelinated just behind the lamina cribrosa but lack a neurilemma. Once the optic nerve exits the globe, it is enveloped by the pia, arachnoid, and dura mater, consistent with other components of the central nervous system.

choices.text: The unmyelinated axon traverses the retina in the nerve fibre layer
Orthograde transport occurs at a speed of 200-1000 mm/day only
Retrograde transport occurs at a slow rate

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the axoplasmic transport within the optic nerve is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is D) Both B and C, as orthograde transport does not exclusively occur at a rate of 200 - 1000 mm/day, and retrograde transport does not occur at a slow rate.

  • Axoplasmic transport in the optic nerve occurs in both orthograde (from retina to brain) and retrograde (from brain to retina) directions.
  • The orthograde transport has three components: a slow component (0.5 - 3.0 mm/day) for proteins and enzymes, an intermediate component (mainly mitochondria), and a rapid component (200-1000 mm/day) for subcellular organelles.
  • Retrograde axoplasmic transport, which carries lysosomes and mitochondria from the brain to the eye, occurs at an intermediate rate. (Option C ruled out)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

The unmyelinated axon traverses the retina in the nerve fibre layer (Option A): This is correct. Retinal ganglion cell axons remain unmyelinated as they course within the retinal nerve fiber layer until they reach the lamina cribrosa. Hence, this is not an incorrect statement.

Orthograde transport occurs at a speed of 200-1000 mm/day only (Option B): Incorrect. Orthograde (anterograde) transport has both fast (200-1000 mm/day) and slow (1-10 mm/day) components. Saying "only fast" makes this statement wrong.

Retrograde transport occurs at a slow rate (Option C): Incorrect. Retrograde transport is actually fast, at about 200 mm/day, to carry signals and growth factors back to the cell body. So this statement is wrong.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be affected in an optic nerve lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Photo-stress test is typically abnormal in macular (retinal) disorders, not optic nerve pathologies.

  • The photo-stress test evaluates macular function by measuring the recovery time of vision after exposure to bright light.
  • In optic nerve lesions, visual disturbances like reduced visual acuity, colour vision abnormalities, and visual field defects are commonly seen. (Option A and C ruled out)
  • The pupillary reaction is also affected in optic nerve lesions. (Option B ruled out)
  • The photo-stress test remains largely normal in optic nerve lesions because the macula and photoreceptors themselves are unaffected.
  • In macular disorders, such as central serous retinopathy, the photo-stress test is abnormal due to direct involvement of photoreceptors. Hence, this test helps differentiate macular from optic nerve disease.

choices.text: The 24-2 test evaluates only the central 10° of the visual field.
Mean deviation (MD) indicates localised visual field defects.
Pattern standard deviation (PSD) reflects irregularities in the visual field contour.
The blind spot is mapped in the nasal quadrant.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of primary open-angle glaucoma is undergoing follow-up with Humphrey visual field (HVF) testing using the 24-2 strategy. Which of the following statements regarding this visual field test is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pattern standard deviation (PSD) is a Humphrey visual field index that quantifies localised irregularities in the visual field.

  • Humphrey visual field (HVF) testing is a standard automated perimetry method used to assess functional visual loss, particularly in glaucoma patients.
  • The 24-2 strategy tests 54 points spaced 6° apart within the central 24° of the visual field.

Humphrey Visual Field Test Programs

  • Some of the visual field indices used in perimetry include:
    • Mean deviation (MD) gives an average reduction in sensitivity across the entire field and reflects generalised
    • Pattern standard deviation (PSD) highlights localised, focal defects by measuring how much the field deviates from the normal hill of vision, making it especially useful in early glaucoma.
  • The blind spot, corresponding to the optic nerve head, is located temporally in the field plot as it is on the nasal side anatomically.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

The 24-2 test evaluates only the central 10° of the visual field (Option A): Wrong, because the 24-2 strategy measures the central 24° of the visual field, not just 10°. The central 10° is specifically assessed by the 10-2 program.

Mean deviation (MD) indicates localised visual field defects (Option B): Wrong, because MD reflects the overall average depression or elevation of the visual field compared to normal, not localized defects.

The blind spot is mapped in the nasal quadrant (Option D): Wrong, because the blind spot corresponds to the optic disc, which projects to the temporal field of vision, not the nasal field.

questions.text: Which areas are involved in the visual field defect in the right eye depicted below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts a centrocecal scotoma in the right eye, which involves damage to both the optic disc and the macular region.

  • A centrocecal scotoma is a visual field defect that extends from the central vision (macula) to the blind spot (optic disc), indicating simultaneous involvement of the macula and the optic nerve head..
  • This pattern is most commonly associated with toxic optic neuropathies (like tobacco-alcohol amblyopia), nutritional deficiencies, and Leber hereditary optic neuropathy. The central involvement reflects macular damage, while the extension to the blind spot implicates the optic nerve.

Explanation of other options:

Optic nerve (Option A): If only the optic disc were involved, as in papilledema, there would be enlargement of the blind spot alone.

Macula (Option B): If only the macula were involved, there would be a central scotoma.

Hemiretinal vein occlusion (Option C): Leads to a sudden onset altitudinal visual field defect.

choices.text: Arises secondary to a rise in intracranial pressure
Optic nerve sheath fenestration can be helpful

questions.text: Which of the following statements about papilledema is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Papilledema is strictly a non-inflammatory hydrostatic process.

  • Papilledema refers to the bilateral swelling of the optic disc resulting from raised intracranial pressure (ICP), and its underlying mechanism is axoplasmic stasis. (Options A and B ruled out)
  • An intracranial tumour located anywhere in the brain can lead to papilledema, with the highest incidence occurring in tumours of the midbrain, parieto-occipital region, and cerebellum.
  • Tumours situated in the anterior cranial fossa are less likely to cause papilledema and typically do so only in the later stages.
  • Other intracranial causes are brain abscess, aneurysms, subarachnoid haemorrhage, pseudotumor cerebri, and hydrocephalus.
  • Malignant hypertension can also result in papilledema, primarily through increased intracranial pressure, although in cases like grade IV hypertensive retinopathy, disc oedema may appear even without elevated ICP.
  • Elevated ICP leads to increased pressure in the subarachnoid space, which surrounds the optic nerve.
  • The changes are seen in the optic nerve head in front of the lamina cribrosa
  • Clinically, papilledema presents with symptoms like transient visual obscurations, headache, and projectile vomiting due to raised intracranial pressure.
  • Stretching of one or both abducens nerves due to raised intracranial pressure can lead to horizontal diplopia - a false localising sign.
  • Imaging, like B-scan ultrasonography, may demonstrate optic nerve sheath distension.
  • In certain cases, surgical optic nerve sheath fenestration may be performed to relieve the pressure. This is particularly considered in idiopathic intracranial hypertension. (Option D ruled out)
  • Optic disc swelling can be seen secondary to causes other than raised intracranial pressure also but it is not known as papilledema.

The following image shows papilledema.

choices.text: Headaches are worst in the early morning but improve through the day
Relative scotoma to green/red colours initially

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms are characteristic of papilledema?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Papilledema commonly presents with transient visual obscurations, morning-predominant headaches, and green and red specific relative scotoma initially..

  • Papilledema, caused by raised intracranial pressure, typically presents with transient visual obscurations or "blackouts," often lasting a few seconds and precipitated by changes in posture such as bending forward or standing up. (Option A)
  • Patients frequently experience headaches that are most intense in the early morning and may improve throughout the day, a hallmark symptom of raised ICP.
  • Colour desaturation, particularly for green and red, is among the early visual disturbances and is associated with the progressive nerve fibre dysfunction in papilledema.
  • As the condition worsens, these symptoms become more pronounced, and enlargement of the blind spot and visual field contraction may ensue due to retinal elevation and chronic optic nerve damage.
  • Other symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and diplopia due to involvement of the abducens nerve (6th cranial nerve), headaches. (Option B)
  • One of the first signs is blurring of the optic disc margins, starting from the upper and lower edges, progressing nasally while the temporal border remains sharp initially. Green and red scotomas (Option C)
  • The disc becomes hyperemic, and the swelling obscures the physiological cup, eventually engulfing the surrounding retina.
  • Retinal oedema progresses, causing the retinal tissue to develop circumferential folds, especially temporal to the disc, known as Paton lines.
  • Veins appear engorged and may lose pulsations. Small arterioles become prominent and red-streaked.
  • As swelling progresses, the disc forms a mound, and vessels bend sharply at its margins. Using direct ophthalmoscopy, a refractive difference of 2 to 6 diopters may be observed between the focus required for the disc surface vessels and that for the retinal vessels located slightly away from the disc.
  • With further congestion, flame-shaped and punctate haemorrhages emerge across the disc and adjacent retina.
  • Exudates appear on the disc and around the macula, sometimes forming a macular star, while cotton wool spots scatter in the posterior pole in the retinal nerve fibre layer.
  • In severe cases, the disc and retina may resemble malignant hypertension.
  • Eventually, vascular compromise leads to infarction, ischemia, and axonal damage. This culminates in pallor and atrophy of the disc known as 'post-papilledema' optic atrophy, which is indistinguishable from post-neuritic atrophy.

choices.text: The central 1.5 mm of the macula is known as the fovea
Only rods are present at the foveola
Normally, no pulsations are seen in retinal arteries
The end of the choroid and retina is marked by the ora serrata

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the retina is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The foveola, the central portion of the fovea within the macula, contains only cones, which are specialised for high-acuity vision and colour perception.

  • The retina is a transparent, multilayered neurosensory tissue with its background colouration provided by the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and choroid.
  • It is clinically divided into zones: the posterior retina (posterior to the retinal equator) and the peripheral retina (anterior to it), allowing precise localisation of retinal findings.
  • The macula lutea (clinical posterior pole), rich in cones, is about 5.5 mm in diameter, and its central 1.5 mm is the fovea, situated roughly 3 mm (2 DD as 1 DD = 1.5 mm) temporal to the optic disc. (Option A ruled out)
  • At its very centre lies the foveola, about 0.35 mm in diameter, which contains only cones and shows a characteristic foveal reflex. It is seen as a bright light reflection from the foveal depression.
  • The foveal avascular zone (FAZ), approximately 0.4-0.6 mm across, lacks retinal vessels and lies at the centre of the fovea.
  • Blood supply to the macular region is from branches of the central retinal artery and occasionally cilioretinal arteries. The retinal vessels originate from the central retinal artery and vein and divide at or near the optic disc into superior and inferior temporal and nasal branches.
  • Arteries are narrower and brighter, while veins are broader and have a purplish tint. Retinal vessels show a central light reflex due to their convex surface.
  • In normal conditions, retinal arteries do not show pulsations, but venous pulsations can be seen in 80-90% of individuals, especially near the disc edge, due to variations in intraocular pressure. (Option C ruled out)
  • The ora serrata marks the anterior termination of the retina and choroid, transitioning into the pars plana of the ciliary body. (Option D ruled out)
  • Common retinal symptoms include reduced visual acuity, visual field defects (scotomas), and altered perception, such as metamorphopsia, with macular disease often reducing contrast sensitivity.

choices.text: It is a case of post-papilledema optic atrophy
It is a type of primary optic atrophy
Permanent changes in the surrounding retina can be seen
Poorly delineated margins of the optic disc can be seen due to gliosis

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with an intracranial space-occupying lesion is referred to you for ophthalmological evaluation. Fundoscopic examination shows the following findings. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image and clinical context point to a diagnosis of post-papilledema optic atrophy, which is a type of secondary optic atrophy.

  • Post-papilledema optic atrophy is a consequence of prolonged optic disc swelling from raised intracranial pressure due to various causes, like space-occupying lesions or idiopathic intracranial hypertension. (Option A ruled out)
  • The vascular compromise and axonal degeneration following sustained disc oedema lead to the disc becoming pale, flat, and atrophic over time.
  • Unlike primary optic atrophy, which occurs without prior disc swelling, post-papilledema optic atrophy is classified as secondary optic atrophy.
  • Hallmark features include obscuration of the lamina cribrosa, poorly defined disc margins due to gliosis, and peripapillary pigmentary retinal changes caused by chronic exudative and ischemic damage to the surrounding retina. (Options B and D ruled out)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

It is a type of primary optic atrophy (Option B): Incorrect. Post-papilledema optic atrophy occurs secondary to longstanding papilledema caused by raised intracranial pressure. Primary optic atrophy, in contrast, develops without antecedent swelling (e.g., due to direct optic nerve injury, demyelination). Hence, labeling it as primary is wrong.

It is a case of post-papilledema optic atrophy (Option A): Correct. This is the typical evolution of chronic papilledema after an intracranial mass or raised ICP, leading to optic atrophy.

Permanent changes in the surrounding retina can be seen (Option C): Correct. Chronic papilledema may leave behind structural alterations like peripapillary gliosis, retinal pigmentary changes, and chorioretinal folds.

choices.text: Both sides show equal magnitude of changes
Swelling is greater on the side opposite of intracranial lesion

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding papilledema is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Asymmetry in papilledema is common, and the side of greater swelling does not reliably indicate the side of the intracranial lesion.

  • Papilledema, caused by raised intracranial pressure, is almost always bilateral, but the severity of disc swelling is often unequal between the two eyes. (Option A ruled out)
  • This asymmetry can arise for several reasons: the lesion may affect one optic nerve earlier, leading to atrophy and thereby less swelling; or, in some cases, swelling may appear more prominent on the same side of the lesion as in tumours of the frontal or middle cranial fossa.
  • Unilateral papilledema is rare, and when present with or without optic atrophy in the opposite eye, it suggests Foster-Kennedy syndrome - a tumour of the olfactory groove or orbital surface of the frontal lobe of the opposite side. It could also be due to a pituitary body tumour.
  • Diagnosing mild papilledema can be challenging, as disc colour alone is not a reliable indicator unless there's a clear and rare difference between both eyes.
  • Fluorescein angiography is useful in such cases, revealing dilated surface capillaries and dye leakage that collects around the optic disc as a vertically oval pool about 5 -10 minutes after intravenous administration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a differential for papilledema?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Retrobulbar neuritis does not cause visible disc swelling and hence is not a differential diagnosis for papilledema.

  • Retrobulbar neuritis is a form of optic neuritis where inflammation occurs behind the optic nerve head, and so the optic disc appears completely normal upon fundus examination, particularly in early stages. This contrasts with papilledema, where disc swelling is the hallmark feature.
  • Multiple causes can mimic papilledema, such as optic disc drusen, papillitis, and pseudopapilledema due to crowded nerve fibres usually seen in hypermetropic eyes. Another cause is peripapillary myelinated nerve fibres. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Drusen of the optic disc are often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and commonly affect both eyes. These calcified, laminated deposits tend to enlarge slowly over time and can make the optic disc appear similar to papilledema, even though the visual disturbances they cause may not correlate with the drusen's location.
  • Pseudopapilledema, also known as pseudoneuritis or pseudo-disc oedema, typically occurs in hypermetropic eyes where a small lamina cribrosa and crowded nerve fibres give a false impression of disc swelling. Clinically, it is characterised by mild elevation (less than 2 diopters), absence of venous congestion, no exudation, and a normal-sized blind spot.
  • In contrast, papillitis (optic neuritis) may appear identical to papilledema upon fundoscopy. The disc swelling is moderate (2 -3 D) and tapers into the surrounding retina.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Optic nerve head drusen (Option A): Can mimic papilledema (termed pseudopapilledema) because the drusen elevate the optic disc, so this is a differential diagnosis.

Hypermetropia (Option B): Small crowded discs in hypermetropia can appear swollen, imitating papilledema. Hence, it is also a differential.

Peripapillary myelinated nerve fibre (Option D): Myelinated nerve fibers near the disc margin may give an ill-defined appearance that resembles disc swelling, so it is a differential.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Optic nerve head drusen is/ are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Drusen of the optic disc are often inherited in an irregular dominant pattern and commonly affect both eyes, occurring in approximately 70% of cases.

  • These calcified, laminated deposits tend to enlarge slowly over time and can make the optic disc appear similar to papilledema, even though the visual disturbances they cause may not correlate with the drusen's location.
  • They are typically found in individuals with small optic nerve heads and may arise due to disrupted axoplasmic flow caused by mechanical obstruction at the disc.
  • Drusen can be associated with various retinal conditions, including angioid streaks, subretinal neovascular membranes, vitreous haemorrhage, and retinitis pigmentosa.
  • On fluorescein angiography, the vasculature of the optic nerve head appears normal, helping to distinguish it from true papilledema.
  • The image below shows optic disc drusen.

choices.text: Visual symptoms are more pronounced in papillitis
Papillitis is associated with more severe swelling of the disc
Signs of an intracranial space-occupying lesion are seen in papillitis
Can be differentiated on ophthalmoscopic examination

questions.text: Which of the following features helps differentiate papillitis from papilledema?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Papillitis can be distinguished from papilledema by the presence of pronounced visual symptoms, whereas papilledema typically does not cause visual impairment in the early stages.

  • Papillitis (a form of optic neuritis) causes marked visual symptoms, including central vision loss, a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), and other visual disturbances.
  • Optic neuritis refers to inflammation along any segment of the optic nerve.
  • Clinically, it is categorised into two types based on whether the affected part of the nerve is visible during an eye examination.
  • If the inflammation affects the portion of the nerve visible at the optic disc, it presents with clear fundoscopic signs, such as in papillitis and neuroretinitis.
  • In contrast, if the inflammation occurs in the retrobulbar segment (posterior to the visible disc), as in retrobulbar neuritis, no ophthalmoscopic abnormalities are observed, and the diagnosis is made purely on symptoms like visual loss and pain on eye movement.
  • The swelling in papillitis is typically moderate (2-3 D) compared to 2- 6 D in papilledema. (Option B ruled out)
  • No signs of intracranial space-occupying lesions are seen in papillitis, unlike in papilledema, which arises due to increased intracranial pressure, which could be secondary to a mass or due to other causes. (Option C ruled out)
  • Papillitis cannot be differentiated from papilledema based on ophthalmoscopy. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which visual field defect is most likely associated with Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) typically results in an altitudinal visual field defect, which is a hallmark of this condition.

  • AION due to infarction of the optic nerve head, most often in the territory of the short posterior ciliary arteries, leading to ischemia of either the superior or inferior half of the optic disc.
  • The result is vision loss restricted to the corresponding half of the visual field, commonly the lower or upper half (altitudinal defect) and is often associated with sudden visual loss and swelling of the optic disc, followed by optic atrophy.
  • AION is of arteritic (commonly due to giant cell arteritis) and non-arteritic forms, having distinct clinical and management profiles.
  • Arteritic AION often presents with systemic symptoms like headache, jaw claudication, and tenderness of temporal arteries, and is an ophthalmic emergency requiring immediate corticosteroids.
  • Fluorescein angiography helps detect hypoperfusion of the disc and is especially useful in arteritic cases.
  • On fundoscopy, arteritic AION typically shows pallid disc swelling without haemorrhages, while non-arteritic AION may exhibit pink disc oedema with flame-shaped haemorrhages.
  • Diagnosis includes investigations such as ESR and CRP for arteritis, and management depends on the type: high-dose systemic steroids for arteritic AION and supportive care for non-arteritic, for which no definitive treatment exists.
  • In arteritic AION (AAION), fluorescein angiography shows severely delayed or absent choroidal filling due to short posterior ciliary artery occlusion, while in non-arteritic AION (NAION), angiography reveals segmental delayed optic disc filling with relatively preserved choroidal circulation.

Explanation of other options:

Enlargement of the blind spot(Option A): Classically associated with papilledema rather than AION, because it arises from raised intracranial pressure, causing elevation of the optic disc and expansion of the blind spot.

Central scotoma (Option B ): Can be seen in conditions affecting the macula and optic nerve.

Arcuate scotoma (Option C ): More commonly seen in glaucomatous optic neuropathy due to damage of the retinal nerve fibres in a specific arcuate pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following blood vessels are compromised in Posterior ischemic optic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posterior ischemic optic neuropathy results from compromised blood flow in the small pial vessels supplying the intraorbital portion of the optic nerve.

  • Posterior ischemic optic neuropathy (PION) affects the retrobulbar (posterior) segment of the optic nerve, where the pial vessels provide the vascular supply. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • This condition is typically associated with systemic vasculitic disorders like giant cell arteritis and SLE, or with hypotensive states like "shock" optic neuropathy.
  • Clinically, it presents with sudden vision loss and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), but notably lacks visible disc oedema or haemorrhages on fundoscopic examination.
  • Since it shares the underlying ischemic mechanism of AION but occurs in a deeper part of the nerve, it can be more challenging to detect early.
  • On ophthalmoscopic examination, it resembles retrobulbar neuritis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Anterior ciliary (Option A): Incorrect. These vessels primarily supply the anterior segment of the eye (episclera, conjunctiva, rectus insertions), not the retrobulbar portion of the optic nerve, so they are not implicated in posterior ischemic optic neuropathy (PION).

Posterior ciliary (Option B): Incorrect. The short posterior ciliary arteries supply the optic nerve head and are involved in anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), not PION.

Central retinal vessels (Option D): Incorrect. The central retinal artery supplies the inner retina, not the retrobulbar optic nerve, so it is not the vessel compromised in PION.

questions.text: Which of the following systemic conditions is not likely associated with optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The systemic condition not typically associated with optic neuritis among the options is malignant hypertension.

  • Optic neuritis is an inflammatory condition that can involve any part of the optic nerve.
  • Clinically, it is classified based on whether the inflammation affects the portion of the optic nerve that is visible on fundoscopy.
  • When the visible part of the optic disc is involved, as seen in cases like papillitis or neuroretinitis, distinctive signs are apparent on eye examination.
  • However, when the inflammation is located behind the eyeball, such as in retrobulbar neuritis, there are no visible changes on fundoscopy, and diagnosis relies on clinical symptoms like visual impairment and pain with eye movement.

The causes of optic neuritis are as follows:

choices.text: Visual loss is progressive for 3 weeks and then shows improvement
Some parameters of visual function, such as colour vision, may remain abnormal

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding demyelinating optic neuritis is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Visual loss is typically temporary with gradual recovery in most cases in typical optic neuritis.

  • In typical (acute demyelinating) optic neuritis, vision loss is generally sudden and usually affects one eye (Option A ruled out).
  • This loss typically progresses over a few days to a week, peaking around three weeks after onset and then begins to improve (Option B ruled out).
  • Perimetry reveals a general reduction in visual sensitivity across the field, with the most pronounced deficits occurring within the central 20 degrees and exhibiting diverse patterns of visual field loss.
  • Greater than 90% of patients recover to visual acuity > 6/9.
  • The age group for typical optic neuritis is around 20 - 40.
  • Vision loss is often associated with pain located behind or around the eye, worsened by movement or pressure. This pain may be linked to tenderness over the area where the superior rectus tendon inserts, which subsides within days.
  • There can be additional deficits in visual function, including diminished colour discrimination (especially red desaturation) and decreased sensitivity to light brightness.
  • Colour vision may not fully recover, and mild residual signs such as a relative afferent pupillary defect or optic disc pallor may be observed, with approximately 10% of cases evolving into a chronic form.
  • There may also be systemic clues, such as preceding flu-like illness or neurological symptoms like limb weakness or tingling. Some individuals notice unusual object movement (Pulfrich phenomenon) or symptom exacerbation with exertion or fever (Uhthoff's phenomenon).
  • Optic neuritis is defined by inflammation affecting any segment of the optic nerve and is clinically categorised based on whether the involved portion is visible during an eye exam.
  • Retrobulbar neuritis often shows a normal disc (especially in adults), papillitis presents with disc swelling and possible flame-shaped haemorrhages (commonly in younger patients), and neuroretinitis shows optic disc inflammation with star-shaped retinal exudates (shown below), usually due to infectious causes or atypical forms not linked to multiple sclerosis.
  • Features like age outside the usual range, absence of pain with eye movements, vision not improving after two weeks, or continued vision loss beyond the first week point toward atypical optic neuritis and warrant further targeted evaluation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with optic nerve hypoplasia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital hypothyroidism is not a commonly associated condition with optic nerve hypoplasia.

  • Optic nerve hypoplasia (ONH) is a congenital condition characterised by a reduced number of optic nerve fibres, often presenting with visual impairment that can range from mild to severe.
  • It is associated with young maternal age and primiparity.
  • It is frequently linked to several systemic abnormalities, especially those involving midline brain structures and the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Common associations include absence of the septum pellucidum (Option A ruled out), corpus callosum agenesis (Option C ruled out), and congenital hypopituitarism (Option B ruled out), forming a triad historically referred to as septo-optic dysplasia (de Morsier syndrome).
  • In severe bilateral cases, early-onset blindness with roving eye movements or nystagmus is common. Milder or unilateral cases may present as strabismus and can be easily overlooked.
  • Visual acuity ranges from normal to severely impaired. A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) may be seen, and both pupils may show sluggish responses in bilateral involvement.
  • The optic disc appears smaller than normal. A foveola-disc centre distance of more than three disc diameters strongly suggests optic nerve hypoplasia. A greyish disc with central cupping and radial vessels may be seen in more advanced cases.
  • A "double-ring" sign (visible sclera surrounding a pigmented band) may also be present, as shown below (black arrow)

questions.text: Which of the following tests are not indicated in a patient with the first episode of typical optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Blood tests for syphilis are not routinely indicated in a new patient presenting with typical optic neuritis.

  • In the clinical workup of a typical optic neuritis case, investigations include visual field analysis, visual evoked potentials (VEPs), and MRI of the brain and orbits with contrast. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • These evaluations help confirm the diagnosis and assess for associated conditions like multiple sclerosis.
  • MRI is particularly useful for identifying demyelinating lesions and is done for the first episode and all atypical optic neuritis.
  • While syphilis testing (like rapid plasma reagin or FTA-ABS) is important in the investigation of atypical optic neuritis, especially in cases with atypical symptoms or systemic signs, it is not a standard part of the initial evaluation in typical presentations.
  • The management of optic neuritis depends on how severely vision is affected, the patient's visual needs, prior episodes, MRI findings, and any identified underlying cause.
  • In typical, idiopathic, or demyelinating cases, vision often improves gradually on its own, with near-complete recovery, although some patients may continue to experience subtle contrast sensitivity deficits.
  • Treatment recommendations are largely based on findings from the Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial (ONTT).
  • For patients presenting with severe vision loss and no history of optic neuritis or multiple sclerosis, and whose MRI reveals demyelination, a short course of intravenous methylprednisolone (250 mg every 6 hours for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day for 11 days with a rapid taper over 3 days) is advised.
  • This regimen has been shown to accelerate visual improvement and reduce recurrence.
  • However, the long-term vision outcome remains similar to observation alone.
  • Even with a normal MRI, multiple sclerosis cannot be fully excluded.
  • IV steroids can still help speed up recovery in more severe or bilateral cases. Oral steroids alone, especially at 1 mg/kg/day, are not recommended due to higher relapse rates when used without prior IV therapy.
  • In contrast, for patients who already have a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis or a history of optic neuritis, watchful observation is generally preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be utilised to image the scolex in a case of optic nerve cysticercosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An optical coherence tomography scan is not typically used to detect the scolex in optic nerve cysticercosis.

  • Cysticercus cellulosae infestation of the optic nerve is rare but causes significant visual loss and can mimic other optic neuropathies.
  • Diagnosis is challenging due to its resemblance to optic nerve tumours. The scolex of the parasite appears as a hyperdense pinhead lesion inside the cyst and can be visualised using high-resolution imaging techniques like ultrasound, CT, and MRI scans with thin sections. These modalities can detect the reflective scolex based on its density and structural features. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • In ocular cysticercosis, parasitic cysts can appear in the conjunctiva, eyelids, or orbit, and may even be seen as floating lesions in the anterior chamber.
  • In more serious cases, larvae may migrate into the subretinal space, triggering exudative retinal detachment, or enter the vitreous cavity, where their toxic secretions provoke a severe inflammatory reaction that can threaten vision. The inflammation is often intense and can compromise multiple ocular structures.
  • The management of optic nerve cysticercosis primarily includes high-dose systemic corticosteroids to suppress inflammation caused by toxins released from the dying parasite, which are thought to contribute significantly to the observed visual loss.
  • Using antiparasitic medications to treat intraocular cysticercosis is avoided since the destruction of the cyst within the eye can provoke a violent inflammatory reaction. This intense inflammation may cause irreversible damage, potentially resulting in phthisis bulbi.

choices.text: Optic atrophy following anterior ischemic optic neuropathy

questions.text: All of the following are examples of post-neuritic optic atrophy except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Optic atrophy following CRAO is an example of consecutive optic atrophy.

  • Optic atrophy refers to the visible changes in the optic disc following degeneration of the optic nerve. Damage to the optic nerve anywhere along its course from the retina to the lateral geniculate body can cause degeneration, not just on the brainward side but also at the ocular end.
  • Primary optic atrophy is due to disease or toxic damage affecting the optic nerve behind the disc without any prior local inflammation. It commonly results from multiple sclerosis, Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy, compressive lesions (e.g., tumours), or toxic agents such as methanol.
  • Damage at the disc level from inflammation, as in papillitis or papilloedema, is termed postneuritic or secondary atrophy. Examples include optic atrophy following anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, papillitis, and chronic papilledema. (Option A, B, and C ruled out)
  • Another variant is glaucomatous atrophy, marked by cupping of the disc.
  • Clinically, optic atrophy presents with a pale optic disc and vascular changes. The pallor affects the entire disc and should be distinguished from physiological cupping. Loss of colour is not due to fibre atrophy but decreased blood flow and vessel loss.
  • Brain tumours may cause primary atrophy if they compress the optic chiasma, or secondary if papilledema The difference lies in whether the disc was inflamed or normal before atrophy.
  • Consecutive atrophy occurs due to retinal or choroidal pathology. The disc becomes waxy and yellow, edges become poorly defined, and blood vessels shrink significantly. Causes include extensive retinal photocoagulation, retinitis pigmentosa, and central retinal artery occlusion.
  • No treatment reverses optic atrophy. Prognosis depends entirely on early diagnosis and management of the underlying cause.

choices.text: Shallow and saucer-shaped cupping of the optic disc

questions.text:
A 37-year-old patient reports to OPD with complaints of vision loss post-methanol poisoning. Fundus examination reveals the following. Which of the following statements regarding disc appearance in this scenario is correct?

Which of the following statements regarding disc appearance in this scenario is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the clinical vignette of methanol poisoning and fundus findings is suggestive of primary optic atrophy, which is characterised by shallow and saucer-shaped cupping of the optic disc.

The image below shows secondary optic atrophy.

Explanation of other options:

Lamina cribrosa shows extensive retraction (Option A): Primary optic atrophy does not show extensive retraction of the lamina cribrosa. Only stippling is seen.

Disc margins are ill-defined (Option B): Disc margins are well defined in primary optic atrophy.

Paton lines (Option C): Paton lines are seen in secondary optic atrophy due to disc oedema, resulting in retinal folds.

choices.text: Communication between the retinal artery and vein
Arise de novo due to obstruction to venous drainage
More frequently seen on the temporal side

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding this lesion is/are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows opticociliary shunts, which are more frequently seen on the temporal side.

  • Opticociliary shunt vessels are dilated collateral veins around the optic disc that divert blood from the retina to the choroidal circulation in response to venous outflow obstruction, typically due to compressive optic nerve lesions. (Option A ruled out)
  • Opticociliary collaterals develop from pre-existing capillaries around the optic disc that become dilated and prominent when normal venous outflow is impaired. (Option C ruled out)
  • These vessels reroute blood into the choroidal system, thereby bypassing the obstructed central route.
  • On examination, they appear as large, tortuous vessels, most commonly on the temporal side of the disc, and may be visible only when obstruction is significant. (Option B ruled out)
  • They are commonly linked to compressive optic nerve tumours, especially optic nerve sheath meningioma, though they also appear in cases like optic nerve gliomas, central retinal vein occlusion, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and glaucoma.
  • Clinically, they are often associated with visual field defects, relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), and optic disc changes like pallor or oedema.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are not a feature of toxic optic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Arcuate scotoma is not a feature of toxic optic neuropathy; instead, it typically presents with bilateral vision loss, temporal disc pallor, a centrocaecal scotoma, and defective colour vision.

  • Toxic, nutritional, and hereditary optic neuropathies share overlapping features due to the common pathophysiological mechanism of disrupted mitochondrial ATP production.
  • This disruption is particularly detrimental to the papillomacular bundle due to its high metabolic demand. Clinically, patients usually present with sudden or subacute painless bilateral visual loss, which may range from mild to severe. (Option A ruled out)
  • This is frequently associated with nutritional deficiencies (notably B-complex vitamins), exposure to toxins like cyanide or methanol, and sometimes hereditary predispositions.
  • Symptoms often include impaired colour vision, especially red-green desaturation, and visual field defects, classically a centrocaecal scotoma. The optic disc shows temporal pallor over time. (Options B and C ruled out)
  • Additional features may include paraesthesias, ataxia, or hearing loss in advanced or associated neurological cases. If recognised early, treatment with vitamin supplementation (B, B, B), dietary correction, and cessation of smoking can lead to significant visual recovery over months.
  • However, if the condition is chronic and longstanding, vision loss may become permanent.
  • Toxic optic neuropathies involve damage to optic nerve fibres by external poisons. 
  • Common toxins include tobacco, ethyl and methyl alcohol, lead, arsenic, thallium, and drugs like quinine or carbon disulfide. Anti-tubercular drugs such as ethambutol, isoniazid, and streptomycin are also implicated.
  • These agents may directly harm the optic nerve or secondarily affect retinal ganglion cells. For instance, tobacco-related damage often results from cyanide exposure, particularly in heavy smokers aged 35 -50 years, and is aggravated by vitamin B deficiency. Histologically, affected retinal ganglion cells, especially in the macula, show vacuolation, and the papillomacular bundle degenerates.
  • Treatment centres on halting exposure to the offending agent (e.g., quitting tobacco and alcohol) and supplementing with vitamin B (e.g., 1000 mg intramuscular hydroxocobalamin, initially at short intervals, then tapered). Recovery can be slow, with improvement monitored via visual evoked potentials (VEPs), but prognosis is generally good if intervention occurs early. Recurrence is rare even if moderate tobacco use resumes.

The following image depicts bilateral disc oedema in chloroquine toxicity.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old male patient suffering from insulin-dependent diabetes has come to OPD for routine fundus examination. Clinical imaging is as follows in both eyes. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is/ are incorrect?

Which of the following statements regarding this condition is/ are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Visual field defects in diabetic papillopathy do not reverse with treatment, and disc oedema usually resolves over several months.

  • Diabetic papillopathy is a rare optic disc condition most often observed in adolescents or young adults with juvenile-onset insulin-dependent diabetes. It is considered a variant of anterior ischemic optic neuropathy.
  • It typically presents with either unilateral or bilateral gradual blurring of vision, though it can also be asymptomatic and found incidentally.
  • The hallmark finding is a swollen optic disc with overlying telangiectatic vessels, which is a valuable clue for diagnosis. Central or arcuate visual field defects are possible, but overall visual acuity is usually not significantly compromised.
  • Neuroimaging is essential, especially when both eyes are involved, to exclude serious intracranial causes such as space-occupying lesions or pseudotumor cerebri. Neurosurgical evaluation and cerebrospinal fluid pressure assessment may also be required in some cases.
  • Although visual field defects tend to be permanent, the disc swelling usually subsides spontaneously over several months.
  • Two distinguishing features separate diabetic papillopathy from ischemic optic neuropathy: it often affects both eyes at the same time, and optic nerve function tends to remain intact.
  • No definitive treatment is advised, as the aetiology is uncertain and there is no proven link to glycemic control or the severity of diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: Which part of the optic nerve is most likely involved in traumatic optic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Traumatic optic neuropathy commonly involves the intracanalicular part of the optic nerve.

  • Traumatic optic neuropathy typically results from a frontal head injury involving rotational or shearing forces, which damage the optic nerve either directly (by disrupting nerve fibres or blood supply) or indirectly through compression caused by oedema, haemorrhage, or bone fragments from optic canal fractures.
  • The injury usually affects the canalicular portion of the optic nerve due to its immobility, and is most often ipsilateral to the impact site. While unilateral involvement is common, bilateral visual loss may occur if the optic chiasm is injured. Blunt orbital trauma can also cause rare conditions like optic nerve head avulsion.
  • Patients generally present with sudden visual loss, often maximal at the time of injury but occasionally delayed by several hours. Signs include visual field defects and a relative afferent pupillary defect.
  • Fundus findings are often unremarkable initially, but optic disc pallor may develop after 3 - 4 weeks, indicating optic atrophy due to disrupted blood supply. In rare cases, the presentation may mimic central retinal artery occlusion if the intraorbital part of the nerve is involved.
  • CT imaging is crucial for detecting canal fractures and haemorrhages that compress the nerve. High-dose intravenous steroids (e.g., dexamethasone 3 - 5 mg/kg/day or methylprednisolone 20 -30 mg/kg/day) may aid in recovery and should be started within 24-48 hours.
  • If visual improvement is observed, oral steroids are introduced and tapered over two weeks. Lack of improvement or worsening within 1 -2 days, particularly from increasing haemorrhage or oedema, may necessitate optic canal decompression using a transethmoidal or transfrontal surgical approach. Decompression is also advised if vision deteriorates during steroid tapering. Visual evoked potentials may be used to monitor treatment response in patients with poor visual acuity.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Optic nerve head (Option A): The optic nerve head (disc) is less commonly involved in trauma-related optic neuropathy; its involvement usually produces visible fundus changes early, whereas traumatic optic neuropathy often shows a normal disc initially.

Intra-ocular (Option B): The intraocular portion (optic disc) is not the typical site injured in trauma. Damage here would lead to immediate visible swelling, which is not the classic finding in traumatic optic neuropathy.

Intra-cranial (Option D): The intracranial portion can be affected in severe head trauma, but the most common and most vulnerable site is the intra-canalicular portion due to its rigid bony confines.

choices.text: Irradiation has no role in management

High dose IV Methyl prednisolone is indicated in all cases
Optic neuropathy arises due to compression of the optic nerve at the orbital apex

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding thyroid-related optic neuropathy is/are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thyroid-related optic neuropathy arises due to compression of the optic nerve at the orbital apex.

  • In Graves' disease, optic neuropathy arises due to compression of the optic nerve at the orbital apex by enlarged extraocular muscles. While vision loss typically progresses slowly, rapid visual decline can also occur.
  • The severity of optic nerve dysfunction does not necessarily correlate with the extent of proptosis. Patients with minimal or no proptosis and tight orbital anatomy are more prone to optic nerve involvement, and proptosis may act as a compensatory mechanism to relieve pressure. (Option B ruled out)
  • On examination, the optic nerve head may appear normal, swollen, or pale. A comprehensive evaluation includes assessing visual acuity, colour vision, and visual fields.
  • Additional investigations involve measuring proptosis and lagophthalmos, slit-lamp examination for exposure keratopathy, intraocular pressure recording, and ocular motility assessment.
  • Treatment depends on the degree of nerve compromise and is individualised. Mild cases with limited field loss can be managed with oral steroids and monitoring, along with lifestyle modifications like elevating the head while sleeping, avoiding smoking, and using eye protection. (Option C ruled out)
  • If the condition is severe or unresponsive to these measures, intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g/day) is initiated. If no improvement is noted within 24 - 48 hours, orbital decompression surgery becomes necessary.
  • For patients who are not candidates for steroids or surgery, orbital radiation is an alternative, particularly in those unfit for surgery or where steroid use is contraindicated. Low-dose radiation therapy (2000 rad in 10 sessions) has been reported to offer benefit in such scenarios. (Option A ruled out)

Commonly situated at the inferior pole of the disc

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the condition depicted below is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image depicts optic disc coloboma, which arises due to incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure.

  • Optic disc coloboma arises due to defective closure of the embryonic fissure, which normally extends from the optic nerve to the margin of the pupil.
  • It may be unilateral or bilateral and can present sporadically or in association with syndromic conditions like CHARGE syndrome, Goldenhar syndrome, or midline CNS abnormalities. An autosomal dominant form is linked to PAX6 mutations.
  • Fundoscopic appearance varies. The common form presents as an inferior crescent-shaped depression at the lower edge of the disc, frequently seen in hypermetropic and astigmatic eyes with mildly defective vision, even with correction. (Option B and C ruled out)
  • The more severe form shows a bowl-shaped excavation that may be large, extending to a chorioretinal coloboma.
  • The floor of the coloboma may appear white and ectatic due to the absence or thinning of normal retinal tissue. Signs include a larger-than-normal disc, abnormal vessel distribution (often only on the upper margin), and superior field defects on perimetry.
  • The condition may coexist with microphthalmia, microcornea, or colobomas involving other ocular structures like the iris or retina. Complications may include retinal detachment, thinning of the retina, and choroidal neovascularisation.
  • Less common abnormalities associated with coloboma include round depressions on the optic disc, referred to as optic disc pits, which are typically found on the temporal (Option D ruled out)
